content: If you write an @user for a user not subscribed to the stream, you get a warning saying they're not subscribed and won't see it, with a button to subscribe them.
If you delete the @user (such as if it was a typo and you meant to @ a different user), the warning and button stay there.
I think if you delete the last @ for a given user in your message, Zulip should remove the warning about that user not being subscribed.
Thanks for the suggestion! I agree that this would be a nicer experience, but unfortunately it would be quite tricky to implement without causing performance problems.
Could it be optimized to only run if the text you delete includes an @ ?
And, only if there's already an open message for subscribing someone?
I'm not the expert on this, but an @-mention could potentially be removed by either deleting or adding characters (somewhere inside the @-mention).
So it'd need to trigger on any edit, then.
Fair enough; it'd still be nice to have, but if it'd be a substantial performance hit then it isn't worth it.
